revisions.rev:
{{About|Tahrir Square in Cairo}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}} {{Coord|30.044422|31.235696|display=title|type:landmark_region:EG-C}} [[File:Tahrir Square in 1941.jpg|thumb|300px|Tahrir Square in 1941.]]
'''Tahrir Square''' ({{lang-ar|Ù ÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ±}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|MÄ«dÄn at-Taá¸¥rÄ«r}}'', {{IPA-arz|meËdÃ¦Ën ettÃ¦Ä§ËÉ¾iËÉ¾|IPA}}, {{lang-en|Liberation Square}}) is a major public [[town square]] in [[Downtown Cairo]], [[Egypt]].
==History== The square was originally called ''Ismailia Square'' ({{lang-ar|Ù ÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØ¥Ø³Ù Ø§Ø¹ÙÙÙØ©}} ''{{transl|ar|MÄ«dÄn al-IsmÄâÄ«liyyah}}''), after the 19th-century ruler [[Khedive Ismail]], who commissioned the new downtown district's 'Paris on the [[Nile]]' design. After the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1919]] the square became widely known as Tahrir (Liberation) Square, but the square was not officially renamed until the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952]], which changed Egypt from a [[constitutional monarchy]] into a [[republic]]. The square was a focal point for the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]].<ref>{{cite book |author=Vatikiotis, Panayiotis J. |title=The Middle East: From the End of Empire to the End of the Cold War |year=1997 |publisher=Routledge |pages=194 }}</ref>
==Features== [[File:Talet harb roundabout-cairo-egypt.JPG|thumb|Tahrir Square at night with [[traffic circle]], view northwest from [[Talaat Harb Street]]]] [[File:Modan Tahrir (2005-05-343).jpg|thumb|View south towards the [[The Mogamma|Mogamma]] building and Omar Makram statue]] At the centre of Tahrir Square is a large and busy [[traffic circle]]. On the north-east side is a plaza with a statue of nationalist hero [[Alexandria expedition of 1807#Occupation of Rosetta|Omar Makram]], celebrated for his resistance against Napoleon I's invasion of Egypt, and beyond is the Omar Makram Mosque.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.touregypt.net/featurestories/midanaltahrir.htm |title=Midan Al-Tahrir, Liberation Square |publisher=Tour Egypt}}</ref>
The square is the northern terminus of the historic [[Qasr al-Ayn Street|Qasr al-Ayni Street]], the western terminus of [[Talaat Harb Street]], and via [[Qasr el-Nil Street|Qasr al-Nil Street]] crossing its southern portion it has direct access to the [[Qasr al-Nil Bridge]] crossing the nearby [[Nile River]].
The area around Tahrir Square includes the [[Egyptian Museum]], the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party-NDP]] headquarters building, the [[The Mogamma|Mogamma]] government building, the [[Headquarters of the Arab League]] building, the Nile Hotel, Kasr El Dobara Evangelical Church and the original [[Khairy Pasha palace|downtown campus]] of the [[American University in Cairo]].
The [[Cairo Metro]] serves Tahrir Square with the [[Anwar al-Sadat|Sadat]] Station, which is the downtown junction of the system's two lines, linking to [[Giza]], [[Maadi]], [[Helwan]], and other districts and suburbs of [[Greater Cairo]]. Its underground access viaducts provide the safest routes for pedestrians crossing the broad roads of the heavily trafficked square.
==Public use and demonstrations== Tahrir Square has been the traditional site for numerous major protests and demonstrations over the years, including the [[1977 Egyptian Bread Riots]], and the March 2003 protest against the [[War in Iraq]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/s_345537.html |title=Egyptian reformers taking it to streets |publisher=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review |author=Hiel, Betsy |date=19 June 2005}}</ref>
===2011 Egyptian Revolution=== {{main|2011 Egyptian Revolution}} [[File:Demonstrators on Army Truck in Tahrir Square, Cairo.jpg|thumb|Protesters on an army vehicle during the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]] in Tahrir Square.]] Tahrir Square was the focal point of the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]] against former president [[Hosni Mubarak]].<ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12289475 Egypt protests: Anti-Mubarak demonstrators arrested], 26 January 2011. Accessed 2011.01.26.</ref> Over 50,000 protesters first occupied the square on 25 January, during which the area's wireless services were reported to be impaired.<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> In the following days Tahrir Square continued to be the primary destination for protests in Cairo.<ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12312330 "Egypt protests: curfew defied in Cairo and other cities"] 29 January 2011. Accessed 2011.01.29.</ref> On 29 January Egyptian [[fighter aircraft]] flew low over the people gathered in the square. On 30 January, the seventh day of the protests, [[BBC]] and other correspondents reported that the number of demonstrators had grown to at least 100,000,<ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12320959 "Egypt protesters step up pressure on Hosni Mubarak"] 31 January 2011. Accessed 2011.01.31.</ref> and on 31 January [[Al Jazeera]] correspondents reported that the demonstrations had grown to at least 250,000 people.<ref>Al Jazeera News: [http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/30/live-blog-311-egypt-protests Live blog 31/1 â Egypt protests], 31 January 2011. Accessed 2011.01.31.</ref> On 1 February, Al Jazeera reported that more than 1 million protesters peacefully gathered in the square and adjacent streets.<ref>Al Jazeera News: [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011215827193882.html Protesters flood Egypt streets], 1 February 2011. Accessed 2011.02.01.</ref> However, such media reports that so many people congregated in Cairoâs largest public square are believed to be exaggerated for political purposes and, accordingly to [[STRATFOR]] analysis the real number of gathered protester never exceed 300,000 people.<ref>STRATFOR: http://www.stratfor.com/analysis/20110131-gauging-size-egyptian-protests Gauging the Size of the Egyptian Protests, 31 January 2011. Accessed 2011.06.14.</ref><ref>STRATFOR: http://www.stratfor.com/analysis/20110201-update-size-protests-cairo Update on the Size of Protests in Cairo, 1 February 2011. Accessed 2011.06.14.</ref>
[[File:Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png|thumb|People congregated in Tahrir Square on 9 February 2011]] The square became established as a focal point and a symbol for the ongoing Egyptian democracy demonstrations. On 2 February violence erupted between the pro-[[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak]] and pro-democracy demonstrators here, followed by the 3 February 'Friday of Departure' demonstration, one of the named "day of" events centered in the square. Within a week, due to international media coverage, the image and name of Tahrir Square became known worldwide.<ref>Al Jazeera News: [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112391254105223.html "Battle of Tahrir Square"] 3 February 2011 . Accessed 2011.02.03</ref>
A [[Facebook]] page called ''"Tahrir Square"'' Ù ÙØ¯Ø§Ù Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ± was maintained by a rotating staff of twenty during the uprising, particularly to offset the lack of and/or distorted coverage of events and responses in the state-run media outlets.<ref>Fahim, Kareem and Mana El-Naggar; Liam Stack and Ed Ou contributed reporting, [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09ghonim.html?_r=1&scp=1&sq=Mona%20El-Nagger&st=cse "Emotions of a Reluctant Hero Galvanize Protesters"], ''The New York Times'', 8 February 2011 (9 February 2011 p. A14 NY ed.).</ref><ref>[http://www.facebook.com/pages/mydan-althryr-tahrir-square/188629931158568 ''tahrir square''], Facebook page. Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
An iPhone and Blackberry app called Tahrir Square was launched on 6 May 2011. It offers a unique opportunity for Egyptians everywhere to provide their collective and unfiltered opinion on the hottest topics of the new Egypt. The results presented clearly in simple graphs and tables for everyone to see. The interactive mobile app will be distributed on a regular basis to over a dozen Egyptian news agencies, government offices, the military council, and hundreds of social media sites.<ref>[http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/05/12/idUS28528+12-May-2011+MW20110512 ] Reuters. Retrieved 11 May 2011.</ref>
The 18-day revolt centered in the square provided the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] an opportunity to remove Mubarak from power on Friday 11 February 2011, when the president officially stepped down from office.<ref>STRATFOR: http://www.stratfor.com/weekly/20110213-egypt-distance-between-enthusiasm-and-reality Egypt: The Distance Between Enthusiasm and Reality, 14 February 2011. Accessed 2011.06.14.</ref> The announcement that Mubarak had passed all authority to the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|Council of the Armed Forces]], was made by longtime intelligence chief and new vice president [[Omar Suleiman]].<ref>Kirkpatrick, David D. and Anthony Shadid from Cairo. Other reporting was contributed by Kareem Fahim, Liam Stack, Mona El-Naggar and Thanassis Cambanis from Cairo, and Alan Cowell from Paris, [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/12/world/middleeast/12egypt.html?hp âMubarak Steps Down, Ceding Power to Militaryâ] ,''The New York Times'', 11 February 2011.</ref><ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12433045 "Egypt crisis: President Hosni Mubarak resigns as leader"]; 12 February 2011; Accessed 2011.02.21.</ref> Tahrir Square erupted in a night-long celebration after the twilight announcement, with shouts such as "Lift your head up high, you're Egyptian," "Everyone who loves Egypt, come and rebuild Egypt," and others.<ref name="bbcsoueif">BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12393795 "Ahdaf Soueif: Protesters reclaim the spirit of Egypt"]; 13 February 2011; Accessed 2011.02.21.</ref> The next day Egyptian Cairen women and men came to clean up the square, "they came and cleaned up after their revolution," relaying 'projectiles' in the cobblestone paving and removing eighteen day's worth of trash and [[graffiti]].<ref name="bbcsoueif"/>
===Post-revolution=== Tahrir Square, with 'democracy anniversary' celebrations and visits from foreign dignitaries, continues to be a symbol of the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.<ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12507217 "Thousands attend political rally in central Cairo"]; 18 February 2011; Accessed 2011.02.21.</ref><ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12525310 "David Cameron meets locals around Cairo's Tahrir Square"]; 21 February 2011; Accessed 2011.02.21.</ref> British Prime Minister [[David Cameron]], [[Catherine Ashton]], the [[High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy]] of the [[European Union]], [[Hillary Clinton]], [[Secretary of State]] of the [[United States]], [[John Kerry]], Chairman of the American [[Senate Committee on Foreign Relations]], [[Kevin Rudd]] Foreign Minister of Australia, and American actor [[Sean Penn]] visited Tahrir Square after the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]].
One of the ships in the planned [[Freedom Flotilla II]], intended to break the Israeli blockade of Gaza, was named Tahrir after the square. Among its passengers was [[Haaretz]] reporter Amira Hass. Ultimately, the sailing did not take place.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/fear-and-no-clean-clothing-amira-hass-preparing-to-sail-for-gaza-1.369611</ref>
On 29 June 2011, Egyptian police attacked rioting Egyptian youth in the square with tear gas and other non-lethal materials. The youth had been demanding that trials of senior officials overthrown in the [[2011 Egyptian Revolution]] proceed more quickly. The Interior Ministry blamed the unrest on disruptive and subversive groups.<ref>http://www.haaretz.com/news/mideast-in-turmoil/egypt-police-fire-tear-gas-at-protesting-youths-in-tahrir-square-1.370172</ref>
